dt: {bc}to look through thoroughly in often a rough way

dt.t: … he and 15 staff members watched agents {wi}ransack{/wi} the office.
In desperation, I {wi}ransacked{/wi} my refrigerator for something else to whip up.
Most novelists {wi}ransack{/wi} their lives for that first novel; it might be called involuntary reporting.

dt: {bc}to search through and steal from in a forceful and damaging way {bc}{sx|plunder||}

dt.t: Louis XVI was persuaded to risk a navy far from its own shores and to {wi}ransack{/wi} the French arsenals for arms and ammunition …

et: Middle English {it}ransaken{/it}, from Old Norse {it}rannsaka{/it}, from {it}rann{/it} house + {it}-saka{/it} (akin to Old English {it}sēcan{/it} to seek) {ma}{mat|seek|}{/ma}
shortdef: to look through thoroughly in often a rough way
to search through and steal from in a forceful and damaging way : plunder
